column1: As a non-credit bearing course, it aims to enhance the general knowledge of students outside of their major studies that guest speakers are invited to share topics covering social, ethical, cultural, religious, political, artistic or aesthetic issues.

This course aims at helping new students to develop an understanding and appreciation of university education and to adapt to campus life. Origins, traditions and objectives of universities, and their relationships with individual and society will be introduced. Distinctions between adult learning and juvenile learning, high-school and university studies will be elaborated. Advice and effective social and study skills will be provided to facilitate smooth transition. The Founder’s Ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) Spirit will also be covered.

This course is for new students to develop an understanding and appreciation of university education and to adapt to campus life. It covers origins, traditions and objectives of universities; Founder’s ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) Spirit, relationships with individual and society. Advice and effective social and study skills are provided to facilitate smooth transition through workshop.

A team is a group of two or more people who have a common objective or purpose with a commitment to collective and incremental improvement. Great teams, like great leaders, are made, not born. Two concepts, trust and commitment, are the glue that holds teams together. The objective of this course is to train the students to be a leader who can foster these two aspects of the team.In this course, the students will learn the attributes of trust-building and commitment-building through lectures, workshops, and outdoor activities. The students will also participate in team projects designed by the College. By this chance, they will practise their knowledge and skills through thorough guidance by College supervisors.

This course aims at introducing the main course of changes in Chinese history and the value of Chinese cultural heritage. Through lectures and discussions, it covers major issues in development of Chinese history. Examples of the topics include the origin of Chinese culture, milestones in dynastic history, intellectual thoughts and social structures. Field trip and tutorial help students to understand the relationship between Chinese history and Hong Kong development. After taking this course, students are expected to develop critical thinking and analysis skills in a historical context, and further interests in the learning of Chinese culture.

Napoleon Bonaparte once said of China: “China is a sleeping lion. Let her sleep, for when she wakes she will move the world.” Today, China has risen to become the second largest global economic power; and some experts even predicted that her economy is poised to overtake the US economy by year-2035. Is Napoleon’s prophecy going to come true? China has remained an enigma to the rest of the world. Traditional China’s accomplishments towards medicine, painting, architecture, martial art music and dance had impressed the world and her inventions such as paper, gunpowder, compass, and printing had helped move Europe to the modern age. This course aims to examine the evolvement of the Chinese civilization and factors affecting how China interacts with the rest of the world. It will also explore the extent and impacts of intercultural exchanges between China and the world. The course will also look at the role Hong Kong played in China’s interaction with foreign powers in the past and assess opportunities afforded Hong Kong in the implementation of the Chinese “One Belt, one Road” initiative.In conclusion, the course will assess the swift rise of contemporary China, and the aftermaths brought by her rapid industrialization. The course will try to answer if China will fulfil Napoleon’s prophecy.

This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to plant-based lifestyle. Particular thematic issues such as global warming and pollution, food crisis, diet and health, animal rights, social justice as well as green economy related to livestock industry and food system will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of omnivore diet and lifestyle to their personal life, the animals and the planet as a whole.

This course examines the nature of manner and etiquette systems in the context of interpersonal as well as intercultural communications through exploring its history and development. As part of the social norms, manner and etiquette systems seem to be more universal with increasing socializations in a more globalized world, especially in the business sector. There are still ongoing debates that some countries still preserve their own manner and etiquette systems in some splendid ceremonies and events. This course further studies the factors and socialization processes that shape manner and etiquette system, while specific application will refer to the culture of business in term of practices and behaviours.

This course aims to introduce nature’s genius in the diversity of flora and fauna of Hong Kong and other places. It is specially designed for students in their second year of study or above. The goal is to raise students' awareness of nature’s hidden beauty and genius, including biodiversity and biomimicry. Coursework includes lectures and outings led by experts in their fields, field trip reports, analysis and interpretation of wildlife films in class, feedback on video-clips, a multimedia art exercise, and a biodiversity quiz. Students will learn to appreciate and treasure biodiversity through guided tree walks, bird watching, butterfly photography, and powerful ideas of Nature as our mentor, measure and model in solving human problems. No prior knowledge of biodiversity, or training in multimedia or photography is required, but a sense of wonder, a spirit of inquiry, and passionate curiosity in Nature’s genius.

This course provides an understanding of the nature of innovation related to the growth, success and future development of the service industry on the local and global scales. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of how both anticipated and unanticipated changes may influence tourism, hospitality and MICE (i.e. Meeting, Incentive, Convention and Exhibition). The roles of innovation and creativity in responding to change are also emphasized. Consequently, the course addresses aspects of key management problems, needs, developments and approaches that effectively utilize technology and innovation in the service industry. It also encompasses an understanding of various information and other technological methods utilized in the functional areas of development, operations, management, marketing and financial management.

Kunqu and Peking Opera are Chinese classical traditions and cultures. The aim of this course is to nurture students' appreciation ability and to deepen their understanding on Kunqu and Peking Opera.This course serves as a foundation to further study at an advanced level and encourages future participation in Kunqu and Peking Opera performance.

This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to globalization. Particular thematic issues such as economy, environment and sport as well as non-traditional security issues in the fields of humanitarian intervention, terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking and global health will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of globalization to their personal life as well as the role of Hong Kong between the East and the West in the era of globalization.

You are what you eat. In modern society, food consumption not only fulfils basic human physiological needs but also greatly impacts people’s fitness and wellbeing. This course helps students to understand the psychological processes and factors underlying their food choice and eating behaviour and acquire knowledge and skills in developing healthy eating habits in college and beyond. Main topics covered in this course include the development of eating behavior, social influences on eating, food choice and consumption behavior, eating disorders and treatments as well as developing healthy eating habits.

This course will give a survey of the development of modern Chinese literature. By reading selected works of major authors, this course investigates the thoughts, the artistry and the significance of modern Chinese short stories, novellas and poems. Besides, it gives a survey of the development of Hong Kong literature by reading the works of major authors. The relationships between literature and history, as well as between literature and society, will be emphasized. The artistic quality of Hong Kong literature and its place in modern Chinese literature will be evaluated.

This course covers a wide variety of material and is highly relevant in understanding rapid changes in Global and Comparative European Politics. Part I of the course provides a brief historical background to European politics and sets the scene for the course, in examining theoretically how contemporary ‘populism’ is defined and conceptualized in the 21st century political landscape. Part II of the course provides the main focus of the course, in focusing on the main causes and drivers that have led to the growth of (a) radical right-wing populism and (b) radical left-wing populism. Three key approaches are drawn on in Part II of the course, with comparative studies, survey research (public opinion) and case studies across Western Europe and Central-Eastern Europe allowing students to understand about the diversity and variations of populism in the contemporary political landscape. Part III of the course introduces students to critical debates and evaluations on the ‘rise’ of populism and just how important understanding this political phenomenon is for (a) the implications for contemporary democracy and governance in EU member states, alongside (b) how populism on the ‘right’ and ‘left’ of the political spectrum is challenging the future EU project. Part III of the course also draws briefly on comparisons between the primary causes of ‘populism’ in the European context, to the causes of ‘localism’ in the Hong Kong context.The final part of the course also revisits the premise and assumption made in Part I of the course, about the historical stability of the European political landscape by outlining how a shift has taken place, with ‘a new form of politics’ now existing in European politics. Stability and patterns of partisan alignment have now been replaced by instability and widespread patterns of electoral volatility.

As an international city, Hong Kong has been praised in world class financial services; one of the most efficient governments in the globe; a vibrant and pluralistic globalized city which can serve as the bridge between China and the West even after the handover in 1997. The above Hong Kong myths are valid to some extent, but very often people in Hong Kong have neglected the successful driving forces behind. More importantly, could Hong Kong’s successful development be sustained in a long run? This is an introductory course on contemporary Hong Kong issues. This course applies an interdisciplinary approach and aims at introducing students to basic concepts from Hong Kong’s economics and trade, to administrative and political system of Hong Kong, as well as the role of Hong Kong in international relations.

This course introduces the materials and tools, techniques in brushwork, ink tone variations, and colouring to beginning students of Chinese painting. It also focuses on the techniques of painting in an expressive manner i.e. in the literati tradition of “writing the idea”. In this regard, Chinese calligraphy and painting techniques, as well as the forms of expression are covered.

This course aims to promote students’ awareness and understanding of various issues related to emotional wellness through an online learning platform. The content of the online platform is developed by CLEAR with the collaboration of various teams in CUHK. It covers some common wellness issues encountered by our students, such as perfectionism, anxiety and academic stress.

Compassionate communication helps people remain empathetic with ourselves and each other, even in situations fraught with anger or frustration. It helps us to speak to others without blaming and to hear personal criticisms without withering. This approach can be used in nearly any situation — from dealing with troublesome peers in schools to ironing out rough patches with parents at home.

Behavioral science is a cross disciplinary approach to understanding the human mind and its decision process. It is a combination of scientific research in social psychology, cognitive psychology, and economics. Behavioral science theories have been used to better understand how humans perceive, think, and make decisions. The objective of this course is to enhance your understanding of the fundamental factors that drive human behaviors. By understand these factors, you may gain better insights into analyzing your own behaviors and developing strategies for behavioral management. For example, we will teach learning theories (how certain ideas become associated with each other over time; how people learn through conditioning processes) and use these theories to explain behaviors we observe in daily lives [1] [2]. We will also discuss three major theories from the Behavioral Economics literature, including “prospect theory”, “mental accounting”, and “hyperbolic discounting / intertemporal choice”. These theories will help us understand how people value money, why human valuation of money does not simply depend on the nominal value of the money, and how people mentally track expenditures. Students who would like to read about these topics before course registration may consult the following one-page articles: [3], [4], [5] We will also introduce a simple model that guides behavioral change. We will discuss the EAST framework developed by the Behavioral Insight Team. Although the framework was originally developed for policymakers to guide their policy development, everyone can use the framework to guide their own behaviors.
